prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For having a sleepover with my (21M) friend (22F) and not asking my girlfriend (20F)?
Title is pretty self explanatory but here goes.

One of my closest friends at uni, Annie (who is in a long term relationship) came over one night to have a couple of drinks before heading to a party. One of our friends bailed and we didn’t want to go to the party alone so we watched TV and smoked a couple of Js. The TV is in my room and we fell asleep together. 

My girlfriend of 2 years was at a concert with a girl friend at the time and since we had decided not to go to the party anymore went back to her place instead of coming over.

I told her the next morning that Annie fell asleep in my bed and thought nothing of it for the next few days.

The next time I saw her she sat me down and very seriously explained why she thought what had happened was super inappropriate, she also brought up a bunch of stuff that I hadn’t noticed. Like how she thought Annie would overstep boundaries by playing with my hair and holding my hand at a festival while my girlfriend was walking alone behind. This stuff did happen but I meant nothing by it and love my girlfriend to death. 

My girlfriend did say that I hadn’t done anything wrong because I had never initiated this, but I also hadn’t noticed that it had bothered her.

She said that the whole situation probably wouldn’t have bothered her if it weren’t for one conversation.

We have often talked about having threesomes and which of our friends we would sleep with. Obviously not seriously but we just find it interesting to explore each other’s tastes-and I said Annie. 

After her pointing this out I feel like I’m hyper aware of how I am acting around Annie and I fear it will change our friendship.

AITA for feeling that my GF blowed this out of proportion and letting this affect my friendship with Annie? 

TL;DR : My girlfriend got angry with me because my friend slept over in my bed and she thinks this friend crosses the line too much.


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is that the author had a sleepover with a female friend, Annie, in his room. The girlfriend found out and was upset, especially because there was a past conversation where they joked about threesomes involving Annie. The author feels the girlfriend overreacted, but he's worried about his friendship with Annie.

First, I need to consider the girlfriend's perspective. She's in a two-year relationship, so trust and boundaries are important. The fact that they had a conversation about threesomes and the author mentioned Annie might have triggered her feelings. Even if the author didn't mean anything by it, the girlfriend could feel that the sleepover crossed a line, especially since they were in his room and fell asleep together. The girlfriend's reaction is about feeling uncomfortable with the boundaries between the author and his friend.

On the other hand, the author didn't intentionally overstep. He didn't initiate anything, and he hadn't noticed her discomfort before. The key points here are communication and mutual understanding of boundaries. The girlfriend did say the author didn't do anything wrong, but the issue is that he wasn't aware of how his actions made her feel. So maybe the author isn't wrong in his actions, but he might be wrong for not being aware of how those actions affected his girlfriend. The problem is about communication and emotional awareness rather than intentional wrongdoing.

Also, the fact that the author and Annie are close friends, and the girlfriend feels that Annie crosses boundaries (like playing with hair, holding hands) adds to her stress. The author not noticing these things could indicate a lack of attention to his girlfriend's feelings, which is a relationship issue. However, the author didn't do anything malicious. So maybe the answer is B, the author isn't in the wrong, but he needs to work on communication.
